title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
Visualizing Data in Wildlife Research

The Power of Data Visualization
Data visualization is an essential tool for understanding complex patterns, trends, and relationships within data. By transforming raw numbers into meaningful graphics, we can communicate insights more effectively and uncover patterns that might otherwise go unnoticed. One of the most influential frameworks for creating visualizations is the Grammar of Graphics, which provides a structured approach to building data-driven graphics. This concept, popularized through ggplot2 in R, allows us to construct visualizations by layering data, aesthetic mappings, geometries, and statistical transformations.


My Research: Exploring Bighorn Sheep Ecology
I am a Master’s student at the University of Idaho, studying bighorn sheep habitat use and population dynamics. My research focuses on how ewes’ interactions with their environment influence survival, as well as how social structures impact habitat selection and population dynamics. Through this blog, I will explore data visualization techniques to analyze spatial ecology, survival, and habitat selection, demonstrating how effective visualizations can enhance ecological research.


What to Expect from This Blog
This blog will be a place for me to track my progress, exploration, troubleshooting, and successes with coding data visualizations. By documenting my process, I aim to create a personal reference guide to help myself navigate challenges and refine my skills. Along the way, I hope that sharing my experiences will also be helpful to others who are working with ecological data, R programming, and visualization techniques.

title: Action-Target Pairs: Visualizing Bighorn Sheep Behavior
text:
Understanding how bighorn sheep behave in different group sizes provides insight into their survival strategies and social dynamics. Using visualization, we can explore patterns in vigilance and other behaviors to see whether larger groups of sheep exhibit different levels of attentiveness.
In the field of data visualization, we use Action-Target pairs to define how we interact with data. Actions describe the goal—whether we are discovering new patterns, presenting findings, or exploring relationships—while targets define what aspect of the data we focus on, such as trends, attributes, or spatial relationships.

Task Abstraction
In this post, I will construct two visualizations and define them in terms of Action-Target pairs:
Plot 1: Group Size vs. Number of Vigilant Individuals

Action: Discover Trends – I aim to explore whether vigilance increases with group size.
Target: Trends in Behavioral Data – I will observe patterns in vigilance levels across different group sizes.

Plot 2: Group Size vs. Number of Animals Performing All Behaviors

Action: Summarize Behavior Distribution – I want to see the overall distribution of different behaviors as group size changes.
Target: Attributes of Behavioral Data – This will illustrate how different behaviors scale with group size.



Biological Context
Group living in animals is often associated with benefits such as increased predator detection and enhanced foraging efficiency. In bighorn sheep, vigilance—a behavior where individuals scan their surroundings—plays a critical role in detecting predators. However, vigilance can be costly if it takes away from time spent foraging. One hypothesis is that in larger groups, individual vigilance decreases because more animals are contributing to predator detection.
By visualizing these relationships, we can determine whether vigilance is primarily driven by group size. Additionally, by looking at all behaviors collectively, we can assess whether certain behaviors become more or less frequent as groups grow larger.


Visualizing the Data

Group Size vs. Number of Vigilant Individuals
This plot will help me determine whether the number of vigilant individuals increases proportionally with group size or if there is a threshold beyond which additional vigilant individuals no longer contribute to reducing their risk.

observations %>%
  left_join(group_behavior, by = "group_id") %>%  
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = total, 
                       y = vigilant)) +  
  geom_point(color = "navyblue", size = 2) +
  labs(x = "Group Size",
       y = "Count of Vigilant Animals",
       title = "Group Size vs. Vigilance") +
  theme_minimal()










Group Size vs. Number of Animals Performing All Behaviors
To gain a broader perspective, I will compare group size with the total number of animals performing different behaviors. This will show whether some behaviors become more or less common as group size increases.

observations %>%
  left_join(group_behavior, by = "group_id") %>%  
  pivot_longer(cols = c(foraging, 
                        vigilant, 
                        traveling, 
                        bedded),
               names_to = "behavior", 
               values_to = "count") %>%  
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = total, 
                       y = count, 
                       color = behavior)) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +  
  labs(title = "Group Size vs. Behavioral Counts",
       x = "Group Size",
       y = "Count of Behavior",
       color = "Behavior") +
  theme_minimal()

title: About This Site
text: Hi! I’m Emily, a Master’s student at the University of Idaho working on bighorn sheep research. This blog showcases the why and how of data visualizations related to my work.

title: Understanding My Data
text:
Before visualizing data, it is important to understand its structure and characteristics. Dr. Tamara Munzner’s framework provides a useful approach to classifying data, helping to determine the best visualization techniques. In my research on bighorn sheep ecology, I work with two distinct datasets:

GPS tracking data – spatial data that records sheep locations over time.
Field observation data – tabular data collected during direct observations of behavior and group composition.

Each dataset provides different insights into habitat use, movement patterns, social dynamics, and survival. Below, I outline the key attributes of each and how they contribute to my research.





This dataset consists of GPS locations recorded from collared bighorn sheep, tracking their movements across the landscape. It allows me to analyze how individuals use different habitat types, how far they travel, and whether movement patterns change over time.


      Acq..Time..UTC. Latitude..deg. Longitude..deg. Collar.Name
1 2024-08-30 23:00:44       45.36915       -120.5096     White46
2 2024-08-30 23:00:43       45.42015       -120.4926    Purple02
3 2024-08-30 23:00:42       45.31014       -120.5707    Yellow87
4 2024-08-30 23:00:42       45.31002       -120.5325    Yellow94
5 2024-08-30 23:00:41       45.37524       -120.5178     White33
6 2024-08-30 23:00:38       45.20790       -120.4905     White49






Location: Latitude and longitude coordinates define each GPS point.
Time: A timestamp records when each location was logged.
Habitat Context: The surrounding environment (e.g., grassland, shrubland, rocky terrain) will be linked to each location.




Because this dataset is spatial geometry and time-based, effective ways to visualize it include:

Maps to display movement paths.
Time-series plots to track changes in movement behavior.
Density plots to highlight areas of high use.







This dataset includes direct observations of bighorn sheep behavior, recorded in the field. It provides insight into group composition, social interactions, and activity patterns, which complement the movement data.


  group_id      date habitat aspect weather temp       location total ewes
1  240520D 5/20/2024 outcrop     NE  cloudy   62 horseshoe bend     2    2
2  240521B 5/21/2024 outcrop     SE  cloudy   52 devil's canyon     6    3
3  240522B 5/22/2024 outcrop      N  cloudy   NA      hardstone    50   28
  lambs year_ewes year_rams rams
1     0         0         0    0
2     3         0         0    0
3    19         3         0    0






Behavioral Observations: Activities such as traveling, foraging, and vigilance.
Group Composition: The number of individuals present, including age and sex classes.
Lamb Status: Lamb status for each collared ewe to determine lamb survival.
Temporal Trends: The time of day and conditions during observations.




Since this dataset is primarily categorical and numerical, useful visualizations include:

Bar charts to compare behavior or survival frequencies.
Box plots to show variation in group size.
Stacked area charts to illustrate changes in behavior over time.
